channel.title: Understanding Deobs
channel.description: I went ahead and serached the forums for some understanding of exactly what everyone is attempting to decompile and I'm still at quite a loss. I made this thread in hopes that some knowledgable programmer would settle down for a moment and explain the different between the current RS engine and the past one that has caused the need for a deobber and exactly what it means to have the java client obfuscated. Thanks in advance for any help.

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

I’ve just gotten into deobbing, and over the past two days I’ve gotten a fair ways. It’s really not as abysmally horrible as it’s made out to be. Where there’s a will, there’s a way.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

aznph8playa:

Before I ask more questions I want to thank you again for answering the many inqueries here.

No problem. Hopefully other people will learn something too.

aznph8playa:

I can understand how those kinds of methods and procedures can be cumbersome but is it truly difficult to get past them? Wouldn’t a program that deciphers the actual taks of the runescape client beable to determine what is being done or is that easier said then done?

You’re talking about something that follows the execution of the client to identify parts of it by what they actually do instead of how they look in code? It’s a good idea. Dynamic, or “runtime” analysis is how it’s referred to usually, if rarely around here. As far as I know, only pplsuqbawlz and I have ever tried it, and he’s the only one who ever finished anything - working with it put me onto a new method of static analysis that I think has more potential, since the limitation of runtime analysis is that you must first run the program, which isn’t always desirable with Jagex trying to trap you doing it. Hm…maybe a hybrid of the two would be good? Should think about it.

aznph8playa:

Oh I see… so right now, every update being done to any java bot needs direct human manipulation because working updaters have become difficult. Well I’m not even close to worrying about creating programs that edit/create other programs =oP

Yeah, but really most people are trying to find ways to be free of updates entirely - look at all the loader-clients and ruler’s API hacking.

aznph8playa:

Sensible enough… if I knew how to get a hold of the client so I could deob it. My apologies if it’s something basic that I should already know how to do :o

Meh, about a week ago I forgot where to get the RSC data files. It happens. See RegeX’s post for links.

[quote=“aznph8playa, post:19, topic:4563”]Hmmm… is it really apathy or disinterest? ^_^; I’m guessing the more successful coders no longer find it a challenge to do repetitive work and are simply looking for more challenges.
Oh and, where is that quote originally from?

Thanks again everyone who’s spending time answering these questions! :D[/quote]

I think it was PaulT who said that it’s the accepted state of RS cheating that most people with the ability to make bots don’t have the time or the motivation, and most people with the time and the motivation don’t have the ability.

It’s definitely a challenge - professional programmers spent the better part of a year devising this new engine with “SCREW CHEATERS” in the back of their minds. Deobfuscation is, at least. Very few people who are interested in it are also interested in making a bot. Personally, I start hating any bot project once I have to start coding scripting methods.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

Ok I think I understand what you're getting at. Is JVM an acronym for the process of the computer that executes commands?
The JVM is the Java Virtual Machine. It is the sandbox/environment that starts up, loads all the bootstrap API classes etc, loads your requested class, and starts running it, going through the bytecode.
First off, could you explain to me how do you go about saving the runescape client to your computer?
Navigate to any RuneScape server, and enter a random URL that matches the correct pattern, e.g http://po4.runescape.com/runescape-omg-it-doesnt-matter-what-you-put-after-runescape.jar http://ul2.runescape.com/runescape666.jar

The result will be JAR’d up and you just need to extract it with jar -x or WinRAR or whatever.

I can understand how those kinds of methods and procedures can be cumbersome but is it truly difficult to get past them? Wouldn't a program that deciphers the actual taks of the runescape client beable to determine what is being done or is that easier said then done?
Well, I *think* the task is in identifying the useless code blocks, I'm not entirely sure. For example, we could have: [code]for(int i = 0; i > anInt666; i++) { anInt666 *= someArray[i ^ anInt666]; }[/code]Now, for all we know, the starting condition on that foor loop may never be met in normal conditions, so the code doesn't execute. How do we identify that? And how do we identify that anInt666 is never used apart from here, hence making this block useless?

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

Before I ask more questions I want to thank you again for answering the many inqueries here.

First off, could you explain to me how do you go about saving the runescape client to your computer?

Krichevskoy:

Yes, but that’s just one kind of obfuscation. It makes our job harder, but the one that makes it impossible to work with source while it is present is called control flow obfuscation. In the specific case of Jagex, RuneScape, and Zelix, it’s a brand of control flow obfuscation consisting entirely of opaque predicates.

I can understand how those kinds of methods and procedures can be cumbersome but is it truly difficult to get past them? Wouldn’t a program that deciphers the actual taks of the runescape client beable to determine what is being done or is that easier said then done?

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:18, topic:4563”]You’ve struck the idea that’s the basis of updaters. Unfortunately, most updaters in the past have operated by matching bits of code by regular expressions created to find code in the deobfuscated and renamed “old engine” clients. The changes in the structure of the client, along with our current inability to properly deobfuscate and rename the client, have rendered these useless. There are several other updating methods that I’ve worked on, all of which work better than regex matching in the first place - not to mention that they still work on the new client - so it’s definitely possible for someone to create a bot updater still.

However, those with understanding of the RuneScape client should have no trouble picking out code for functions that they recognize - it’s just programs that have a lot more trouble now.[/quote]
Oh I see… so right now, every update being done to any java bot needs direct human manipulation because working updaters have become difficult. Well I’m not even close to worrying about creating programs that edit/create other programs =oP

Krichevskoy:

Yeah, you could, but in order to easily bypass the encryption (not really encryption, but a cryptographically secure random number generator called ISAAC) you’d have to log the packets from a hook inside the client - at which point, why not just look at the client that you obviously have access to already?

Sensible enough… if I knew how to get a hold of the client so I could deob it. My apologies if it’s something basic that I should already know how to do :o

Krichevskoy:

The JVM knows nothing of the Java language - it only interprets bytecode. “Invalid” identifiers are just one of the things you can do in bytecode that the Java compiler won’t tolerate.

Ok I think I understand what you’re getting at. Is JVM an acronym for the process of the computer that executes commands?

Krichevskoy:

“But that’s how it’s got to be, it’s coming down to nothing more than apathy…”

Hmmm… is it really apathy or disinterest? ^_^; I’m guessing the more successful coders no longer find it a challenge to do repetitive work and are simply looking for more challenges.
Oh and, where is that quote originally from?

Thanks again everyone who’s spending time answering these questions!

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“aznph8playa, post:16, topic:4563”]How exactly do you save the client to your computer?
If you were to run the client obfuscated, would it still return the proper packets to the Runescape servers?[/quote]

Yes. Obfuscation has nothing to do with packets, or even the actual operation of the client (obviously, as the client on runescape.com is obfuscated).

[quote=“aznph8playa, post:16, topic:4563”]Ok, I finally figured out why I was having problems understanding that example. I think there is an error in the example =oP
The deobed version should print out:

int i = 1;
while (i < 1000) {
  ... A[i] ...;
  i ++;
}

Now, I think I understood what you were trying to get at before. So does this essentially mean that if you can follow the program through with odd names and structures that you’ll be able to understood how it’s operating?[/quote]

Yes, but that’s just one kind of obfuscation. It makes our job harder, but the one that makes it impossible to work with source while it is present is called control flow obfuscation. In the specific case of Jagex, RuneScape, and Zelix, it’s a brand of control flow obfuscation consisting entirely of opaque predicates.

aznph8playa:

Could you explain to me why it’s so difficult to understand the structure of the programs? Wouldn’t every modification runescape makes be minimal over time and thus the general outline of their program be similar to what it once was? Then, is it difficult to compare the entire java client runescape has now obfuscated in new a new way to the one that was deobed with ZKM and used to run Aryan?

You’ve struck the idea that’s the basis of updaters. Unfortunately, most updaters in the past have operated by matching bits of code by regular expressions created to find code in the deobfuscated and renamed “old engine” clients. The changes in the structure of the client, along with our current inability to properly deobfuscate and rename the client, have rendered these useless. There are several other updating methods that I’ve worked on, all of which work better than regex matching in the first place - not to mention that they still work on the new client - so it’s definitely possible for someone to create a bot updater still.

However, those with understanding of the RuneScape client should have no trouble picking out code for functions that they recognize - it’s just programs that have a lot more trouble now.

aznph8playa:

Is there anyway to monitor the packets that we send to runescape to help determine how the RS client runs? Or is that a whole nother field of programming?

Yeah, you could, but in order to easily bypass the encryption (not really encryption, but a cryptographically secure random number generator called ISAAC) you’d have to log the packets from a hook inside the client - at which point, why not just look at the client that you obviously have access to already?

[quote=“aznph8playa, post:16, topic:4563”][quote author=RegeX link=topic=5951.msg62221#msg62221 date=1152656532]
The derefercing errors are simply name conflicts where a class x can contain, for example, ‘String A’ and int ‘A’, so it won’t compile in source, but in bytecode, since its referenced as ‘getfield int X.A’
[/quote]
How can it be compiled in bytecode but not in sourcecode? Wouldn’t the sourcecode have needed to store it as a different variable name originally?[/quote]

The JVM knows nothing of the Java language - it only interprets bytecode. “Invalid” identifiers are just one of the things you can do in bytecode that the Java compiler won’t tolerate.

RegeX:

The derefercing errors are simply name conflicts where a class x can contain, for example, ‘String A’ and int ‘A’, so it won’t compile in source, but in bytecode, since its referenced as ‘getfield int X.A’

Yes, I realize that, but I couldn’t find the conflict. Probably should try again some time, since it’s probably 20 versions ahead now.

blacker:

Hey guys I went back to that topic and read up on the conversation. I have a question. Why dont we just modify the old Aryan enough so it works with the new engine and is just as detectable as the old 1 yet just as good. But we can also make the new Aryan for people who would like a less detectable Aryan. That way it would end all the arguments about this. It would sort out the people who try out the new one when it comes out and decide they like the old one better. And instead of them ranting about it, it would be right there for them to use. I never got a chnce to use Aryan so I would probably like to try out the original and the new one, and see which one I like better. Hopefully that will help make things clearer on what I was hoping for.

That’s because the old updater would have to completely redone, and the poor bastard would be duplicating months of work by a team of 5+ of the community’s top 20 coders.

“But that’s how it’s got to be, it’s coming down to nothing more than apathy…”

Read full topic

@blacker wrote:

Hey guys I went back to that topic and read up on the conversation. I have a question. Why dont we just modify the old Aryan enough so it works with the new engine and is just as detectable as the old 1 yet just as good. But we can also make the new Aryan for people who would like a less detectable Aryan. That way it would end all the arguments about this. It would sort out the people who try out the new one when it comes out and decide they like the old one better. And instead of them ranting about it, it would be right there for them to use. I never got a chnce to use Aryan so I would probably like to try out the original and the new one, and see which one I like better. Hopefully that will help make things clearer on what I was hoping for.

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

PaulT:

You save the client from Runescape.com to your computer. Then you rename and deobfuscate it.

How exactly do you save the client to your computer?
If you were to run the client obfuscated, would it still return the proper packets to the Runescape servers?

[quote=“PaulT, post:11, topic:4563”]Nope, it reads them in the same way. As per my example , the two pieces of code mean the exact same thing when read by the compiler:

int i=11;
while (i < 8003) {
  ... A[(i-3)/8] ...;
  i += 8;

=

int i = 1; while (i < 1000) { ... A ...; i ++; } [/quote]
Ok, I finally figured out why I was having problems understanding that example. I think there is an error in the example =oP
The deobed version should print out:

int i = 1;
while (i < 1000) {
  ... A[i] ...;
  i ++;
}

Now, I think I understood what you were trying to get at before. So does this essentially mean that if you can follow the program through with odd names and structures that you’ll be able to understood how it’s operating?

Could you explain to me why it’s so difficult to understand the structure of the programs? Wouldn’t every modification runescape makes be minimal over time and thus the general outline of their program be similar to what it once was? Then, is it difficult to compare the entire java client runescape has now obfuscated in new a new way to the one that was deobed with ZKM and used to run Aryan?

PaulT:

Yes. And they are identical, otherwise…instant ban. Packet editors went out with Autorune a few years ago ;).

Is there anyway to monitor the packets that we send to runescape to help determine how the RS client runs? Or is that a whole nother field of programming?
[/quote

PaulT:

No, the pleasure is all mine. Being a noob is a mindset, not a level of experience with a programming language, and you sir are not a noob.

Thanks so much for the compliment but when I compare my understanding of all of this to your understanding and many of those around these forums, I can do little else but refer to myself as a noob.

[glow=red,2,300]
However, everyone who has posted on this thread has greatly helped me. Thanks so much to all of you for your time and courtesy and I’m sure this will come in handy to others in the future. :)[/glow]

I’m really impressed how quickly the veteran scripters helped to explain things. In my opinion, this is just another example of the greatness of our elite scripters

RegeX:

The derefercing errors are simply name conflicts where a class x can contain, for example, ‘String A’ and int ‘A’, so it won’t compile in source, but in bytecode, since its referenced as ‘getfield int X.A’

How can it be compiled in bytecode but not in sourcecode? Wouldn’t the sourcecode have needed to store it as a different variable name originally?

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

The derefercing errors are simply name conflicts where a class x can contain, for example, ‘String A’ and int ‘A’, so it won’t compile in source, but in bytecode, since its referenced as ‘getfield int X.A’

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

frank_:

I have been lead to believe that you need to use saevion’s (or something similar) deobber to finish the job. The source is readable to a certain extent, though obviously you cannot recompile it. Is saev’s deobber “broken” because patterns it searches for are no longer there, or for another reason? If the latter, please elaborate a little bit

Saevion’s program doesn’t work for three reasons that I’ve found:

  1. It can longer find the control variable upon with the ZKM-created opaque predicates are based. This is a result of a (possibly unintentional) interaction between ZKM and whatever program Jagex is using to scramble variable locations. Saevion’s “zkmstripper” transformer depends on its ControlFinder to locate opaque predicates. The particular ControlFinder that saevion created (“CPControlFinder”) just checks the final (constantpool.getSize() - 1) entry in the main class (i.e., client) constant pool. This works fine against Zelix alone because that’s usually where it puts the variable. However, Jagex’s additional scrambling changes that location and CPControlFinder fails.

  2. It doesn’t address all the obfuscation. Even if “zkmstripper” works perfectly, the classes are still hopelessly scrambled. In addition, I’ve heard that it breaks audio support in the client (I usually provide my own music, so I have no idea if it’s true or not).

  3. The code produced does not compile without renaming. I haven’t got a clue what causes this, but if you try to compile the code that JAD gives you without running the deobfuscated client through Zelix (or whatever you rename with), you get compiler-stopping numbers of errors about dereferencing a variable. I don’t see where it’s being dereferenced, so the only thing I can imagine is a name conflict of some sort (which I also haven’t found).

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

I have been lead to believe that you need to use saevion's (or something similar) deobber to finish the job. The source is readable to a certain extent, though obviously you cannot recompile it. Is saev's deobber "broken" because patterns it searches for are no longer there, or for another reason? If the latter, please elaborate a little bit Wink

Yes, you would need to create a program the looks for patterns and renames and reorganizes code for you (a deobber, to use the parlance of our times) to make it a true obfuscated client, though you could get it to recompile and connect just by decompiling and making some dirty hacks and some simple deobfuscation. However, much of the code would still be indecipherable to you, even if the client did work.

Saev’s deobber doesn’t work for many reasons. The patterns it’s looking for may or may not exist, but it will never find them. Trying to use Savions deobber for the newest client is like trying to fit a square peg into a round hole.

This is probably the future of making sustainable bots and clients, bytecode libraries:

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

Hmm this has helped me understand a few more things about deobbing.

Recently (unfortunately around the day before the new game engine), I decided that I would like to get into the deobbing scene, a few days ago I actually found out how to partially deobfusticate then decompile.

I have been lead to believe that you need to use saevion’s (or something similar) deobber to finish the job. The source is readable to a certain extent, though obviously you cannot recompile it. Is saev’s deobber “broken” because patterns it searches for are no longer there, or for another reason? If the latter, please elaborate a little bit

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

So how do you create a deob of a client?

You save the client from Runescape.com to your computer. Then you rename and deobfuscate it.

With obfuscations, does the RS client simply know that some of the methods are altered and will be written in irregular ways and thus reads them in a manner different from what would normally be read?

Nope, it reads them in the same way. As per my example , the two pieces of code mean the exact same thing when read by the compiler:

int i=11;
while (i < 8003) {
  ... A[(i-3)/8] ...;
  i += 8;

=

int i = 1;
while (i < 1000) {
  ... A ...;
  i ++;
}

So whether you have something called “Method356” or “NPCarmmovementhandler” as long as it is called the same thing and does the same thing, it doesn’t matter what you call it. Except not only does Jagex (or rather, the computer program Jagex uses to obfuscate their program) change the name of the methods, they change the entire heirarchy of the program, which makes it very hard to understand or modify. Once again, obfuscation is hiding the true form of the code, smokes and mirrors, and occasionally more complicated things like control flow abstraction etc.

Sure that seems simple enough but is it necessary to look at the byte code of the class files? Can we not just decompile those classes or is that when we get a deal of gibberish because of the obfuscations that Jagex has enacted?

Using the bytecode makes more sense because it is a more direct way of doing things and creating a new obfuscator would be extremely time-consuming since Jagex could break it again quickly and easily with new ways of obfuscation. Bytecode manipulation is doing things on a higher level, manipulating raw code that Jagex can’t obfuscate.

So then the inputs our clients recieve are directly from Jagex? Are you saying we're really just remaking Runescape and sending packets to Jagex that are similar (hopefully identical?) to those that the normal RS client would send?

Yes. And they are identical, otherwise…instant ban. Packet editors went out with Autorune a few years ago ;).

Thanks as well for your help on this matter. I realize it can be annoying to teach a noobie some of those things which seem so obvious to you.

No, the pleasure is all mine. Being a noob is a mindset, not a level of experience with a programming language, and you sir are not a noob.

Good luck!

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

PaulT:

A deob works just like the normal client Jagex uses, except it isn’t obfuscated. So it’s essentially the same client, renamed and reorganized. It’s extremely difficult to tell what methods are doing and how the client works when you are looking at it in obfuscated form.

So how do you create a deob of a client?
With obfuscations, does the RS client simply know that some of the methods are altered and will be written in irregular ways and thus reads them in a manner different from what would normally be read?

When a java program is compiled it becomes a .class file. Each method in a class is represented by the code, which is a set of instructions for the java virtual machine. The bytecode is very small, hence the small size of .class files.
Sure that seems simple enough but is it necessary to look at the byte code of the class files? Can we not just decompile those classes or is that when we get a deal of gibberish because of the obfuscations that Jagex has enacted?
Our programs and bots usually [b]are[/b] clients, albeit heavily modified clients.
So then the inputs our clients recieve are directly from Jagex? Are you saying we're really just remaking Runescape and sending packets to Jagex that are similar (hopefully identical?) to those that the normal RS client would send?

Thanks as well for your help on this matter. I realize it can be annoying to teach a noobie some of those things which seem so obvious to you.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

Aha! Thank you. That has answered my question completely... well almost. How do these deobs work and how do they explain to us what is happening at the method level on the RS Client?

A deob works just like the normal client Jagex uses, except it isn’t obfuscated. So it’s essentially the same client, renamed and reorganized. It’s extremely difficult to tell what methods are doing and how the client works when you are looking at it in obfuscated form. Take a look at the before and after examples of some simple java code, to get a better idea at what simple obfuscation is:

Before:

int i=11;
while (i < 8003) {
… A[(i-3)/8] …;
i += 8;

After:

int i = 1;
while (i < 1000) {
… A[i] …;
i ++;
}

(from “Protecting Java Code Via Code Obfuscation” http://www.cs.arizona.edu/~collberg/Research/Students/DouglasLow/obfuscation.html)

I see the purpose in trying to understand that functions of the RS Client so that we can better run bots but what information do these deobs provide that allows us to do so and how are they going about obtaining this information?

They simply make the code of client lucid so we can use the methods, for example, mouseclick, or whatever, that we want to use.

vbcoderx has mentioned a few times now the necessity of looking at byte code. Since you, Krichevskoy seem a bit more able to explain these things, do you think you could reiterate for him what the use of looking at byte code is and how it is allowing us to determine how the functions of the RS client are running.

When a java program is compiled it becomes a .class file. Each method in a class is represented by the code, which is a set of instructions for the java virtual machine. The bytecode is very small, hence the small size of .class files.

Also, when we run java bot clients, what kind of inputs and outputs are being recieved? I'm having a slight difficulty in understanding what our programs and methods are actually doing and how they're communicating with the RS clients.

Our programs and bots usually are clients, albeit heavily modified clients.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:6, topic:4563”]If you did that, what would the point of using Java be? Several other languages are much better at that sort of thing. If I wanted a color clicker, I would use SCAR, as I have no particular desire to reinvent that wheel, and it would be faster and have more features from years of development than I could stick in a Java-based copy before I completely lost interest in competing.

No, we use Java because hacking the client itself allows our bots to draw information from the client in a much more direct and efficient way. Unfortunately, it is also more intrusive and therefore more detectable - therein lies one of our current problems. But you’re right, current botting philosophy says that all you need is mouse and keyboard control plus information about the game state. The big differences occur in how that information is obtained - in the past SCAR and client hacks have had their advantages and disadvantages, but right now SCAR is the only one in stable condition.

I have no idea if that addressed anything you wanted to know, but caffeine is bad at answering questions.[/quote]

Aha! Thank you. That has answered my question completely… well almost. How do these deobs work and how do they explain to us what is happening at the method level on the RS Client?

I see the purpose in trying to understand that functions of the RS Client so that we can better run bots but what information do these deobs provide that allows us to do so and how are they going about obtaining this information?

vbcoderx has mentioned a few times now the necessity of looking at byte code. Since you, Krichevskoy seem a bit more able to explain these things, do you think you could reiterate for him what the use of looking at byte code is and how it is allowing us to determine how the functions of the RS client are running.

Also, when we run java bot clients, what kind of inputs and outputs are being recieved? I’m having a slight difficulty in understanding what our programs and methods are actually doing and how they’re communicating with the RS clients.

Thanks again for all of your help.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @vbcoderx vbcoderx
item.description:
@vbcoderx wrote:

WEll i think this topic has been answered good, and im about to go out to eat so i want to say this: There are people claming to have deobs… i beilive some of them because in fact they have posted them… I have seen the new engine deob, but i know it wasn’t the most recent version of the new engine… If u compared the 2 different engines, u could tell that they are very much differnt… all of the variables are strewn about like, used to be “welcome to runescape” used to be in client.java and so did the login methods as well as the logos and backgrounds… well… after searching thru the deobs all these methods are mixed up into all the classes… im positive that the variables i stated aren’t in the client.java/.class anymore! Like i said in my first post, the only way we are currently able to use java bots are bytecode editing and applet hijacking, stuff like that… ARGA like aryan, used accessormethods to interface with the client, now, ARGA has to use applethacjacking to worldswitch, it is still very easy, but still annoying that we have to use external classes to get to the job done… If u have an Rs-resources account and u go to the rs2 cheating section u can see a preview of my bot, it uses modified classes from aryan to world switch but my scripting engine is different… I has to use external classes to get the worldswitching and scriptingengine in(obviously for them both cause no deob) but, using these external classes, is still very affective, the only problem is there is still traps in the rs client!!! so, if i wanted to auto in my bot i must use a noob acc and proxies! other wise i will get ip banned along with me account! If u login to a noob acc on their, expect him to be banned within a few days

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“aznph8playa, post:5, topic:4563”][quote author=Krichevskoy link=topic=5951.msg60505#msg60505 date=1152493668]

Because otherwise you don’t know where to look for the functions or information that you need.
[/quote]

Couldn’t we extract information through bitmaps and things like that? Similar to how Scar runs and operates? What functions do you need other than mouse and keyboard operations for a bot?
I’m sorry for the noob questions ^_^; I have to ask them though because no one seems to do so.[/quote]

If you did that, what would the point of using Java be? Several other languages are much better at that sort of thing. If I wanted a color clicker, I would use SCAR, as I have no particular desire to reinvent that wheel, and it would be faster and have more features from years of development than I could stick in a Java-based copy before I completely lost interest in competing.

No, we use Java because hacking the client itself allows our bots to draw information from the client in a much more direct and efficient way. Unfortunately, it is also more intrusive and therefore more detectable - therein lies one of our current problems. But you’re right, current botting philosophy says that all you need is mouse and keyboard control plus information about the game state. The big differences occur in how that information is obtained - in the past SCAR and client hacks have had their advantages and disadvantages, but right now SCAR is the only one in stable condition.

I have no idea if that addressed anything you wanted to know, but caffeine is bad at answering questions.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

aznph8playa:

[quote]and most people can’t even get a deob to look thru the code! it is obufuscated or basically encrypted… jagex’s obufucater must be a custom made 1 because they used to use ZKM(Zeliz Klassmaster) and many people has written zkmstrippers that took off the zkm obufuscating… and we could succesfully decomile it and read it! thus where we had rs bots!

Again, why do we need to know the details of how the java code in the RS client is operating to make bots at the java level?[/quote]

Because otherwise you don’t know where to look for the functions or information that you need.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

Wow! Thanks for the detailed discription of the problem.

when we updated aryan, the aryan updater searched through the rs deob and removed teh traps, and renames strings and variables...
You mentioned in the beginning of the post that the aryan updater used to remove traps. What exactly do you mean by traps and are these now obfuscated, making it difficult to bot using java? Is there any reason to rename strings and variables besides for own preferences?

Also, does it impede upon a java programmer exactly how the RS client is working? Is it not possible to do something similar to what SCAR does with java where the java client would simply control mouse and keyboard functions instead of playing with how the client actually runs?

and most people can't even get a deob to look thru the code! it is obufuscated or basically encrypted... jagex's obufucater must be a custom made 1 because they used to use ZKM(Zeliz Klassmaster) and many people has written zkmstrippers that took off the zkm obufuscating.. and we could succesfully decomile it and read it! thus where we had rs bots!
Again, why do we need to know the details of how the java code in the RS client is operating to make bots at the java level?

Thanks so much for your time and help.

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @vbcoderx vbcoderx
item.description:
@vbcoderx wrote:

i can answer the somewhat of your questions… the rs game engine has changed so much, we can’t find an relations to rename stuff and understand stuff… like when we updated aryan, the aryan updater searched through the rs deob and removed teh traps, and renames strings and variables… aryan used these strings and variables and stuff to run, like maybe the rs client said class5_sub45 or something, and what ever that did the aryan updater would rename it to what ever it did so maybe if it handled login code then it may be changed thru the hole deob to login or something, well… now… from some deobs and bytecode editing, the same strings aren’t in the same places… and most people can’t even get a deob to look thru the code! it is obufuscated or basically encrypted… jagex’s obufucater must be a custom made 1 because they used to use ZKM(Zeliz Klassmaster) and many people has written zkmstrippers that took off the zkm obufuscating… and we could succesfully decomile it and read it! thus where we had rs bots! If we can’t deobufuscate, then we can’t decomile, and we can’t read the source… IF u try to use the zkm stripper on the current rs classfiles, it brings up lots of errors and can’t make anything of it… same if u try to decomile it… most people used Jad - Fast Java Decompiler but it can’t get much from decompiling… If u had jsut decompiled the old rs engine u would get what was called an unrenamed deob, it still had the zkm encryption on, but it was better than nothing… now we can’t really get much from decompiling, so now really what is left is bytecode editing… It is where the .class file’s bytecode is decompiled to a .j file, basically some java assembly… we can get the rs client connected to login via bytecode editing and some what of edits… like changing “Welcome to RuneScape” can be change via bytecode editing…

hope this helps u a bit…
VbcoderX

Read full topic

item.title: Understanding Deobs
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

I went ahead and serached the forums for some understanding of exactly what everyone is attempting to decompile and I’m still at quite a loss.
I made this thread in hopes that some knowledgable programmer would settle down for a moment and explain the different between the current RS engine and the past one that has caused the need for a deobber and exactly what it means to have the java client obfuscated. Thanks in advance for any help.
